AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Application for a Variation of Condition 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission ref: 19/03148/FUL (Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of a part two storey and part single storey detached dwellinghouse and, a detached single storey Outbuilding/Pavilion, with associated landscaping works) dated 12/02/2020. Variation to include alterations to design of proposal
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of planning permission 19/03148/FUL.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004

Prior to occupation details of the proposed species related to the living wall(s) and their associated irrigation systems and maintenance shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved works shall be carried out in the first planting season following the completion of the development. Any planting which within a period of five years from the completion of the development die, are removed, or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species. All living roofs shall be permanently retained for that purpose only and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To ensure that these works are properly implemented and maintained and in the interest of visual amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the in the south or west elevations of the dwelling unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in C02 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with: 'Impact Assessment & Method Statement' ref 010458 authored by Ivan Button and dated 5th December 2019; 'Arboricultural Method Statement' rev 1; and 'Tree Protection Plan' rev 2. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM 1 0 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cycle parking facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a channel drain shall be installed on the access adjacent to the public footway, in accordance with details which have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for: How the proposed development will be built;Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);The procedure for loading/unloading materials;The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site;Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;Temporary site access;Signing system for works traffic;Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;The location of all ancillary site buildings;The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;Wheel washing equipment;The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andThe method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phases.Deliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because: the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

The site comprises a detached dwellinghouse.14 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 3 objections have been received, relating to:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Effects on trees- PrivacyThe concern raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below. In regards to the concern raised surrounding the shared boundary, officers are satisfied that the appropriate ownership certificate has been signed and that no evidence has been submitted to contradict the submitted information. Boundary disputes between neighbours and other disputes, such as over rights of access, are a civil matter.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Two Storey Side Extension & Porch - Officers acknowledge that the proposed two-storey side extension would fall outside the guidance of the Residential Design SPD (Policy Guidance 36), in regards to preserving a minimum of 1m from the front wall of the house dwelling, as a result of the new front porch. However, Lancaster Gardens has dwellings that benefit from similar side/front extensions and the side extension would otherwise generally follow all other guidelines set out under Policy Guidance 36. Therefore, the proposed front porch and side extension would not have an adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area.Single/Two-Storey Rear Extension- The proposed two-storey rear extension would not be unorthodox in the vicinity of Lancaster Gardens and would generally follow the guidance set out in the Residential design SPD (Policy Guidance 34) and whilst the proposed single/two storey rear extension would have a depth of 5.8m, exceeding the guidance of 3.5m, the extension is on a spacious site and would appear subordinate to the host dwelling. Therefore, the rear extension would not have an adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area.Dormer-The proposed dormer would generally comply with Residential Design SPD, would be small in scale and would not be visible from the streetscene, officers consider that they would not be significant harm to the character and appearance of Lancaster Garden.Overall, the proposed development is considered acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed two-storey rear extension, using the BRE, 45 and 25 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties and neighbouring extensions, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The existing garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking by failing to comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. Officers consider that the omission of the garage would not result in the loss of off-street car parking provision on site, as the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide adequate space for car parking.Therefore, overall, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact on car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A),  the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a terraced dwelling. The site sits within Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - Non designated heritage assets; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed outbuilding would have a large footprint, however it would have a modest height and appropriate roof form. Given that it would have a modest height and sit within a large rear garden, officers consider it would appear proportionate in relation to the existing dwelling and application site. Further, given that similarly scaled outbuildings can be viewed within the immediate surrounding area, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the separation distance between the proposed development and neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. HeritageParagraph 203 of the NPPF 2021 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining anyapplication. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designatedheritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of anyharm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: As noted above the proposal would appear proportionate to the host property and the site it is situated in, and would appear in keeping with host property. As such, officers consider that the proposed extensions would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area. Therefore, officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character, but rather preserve itFire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Representations492no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations were received.ConsultationsRBK Environmental Health officer - No objection.ProposalsUpgrade of external wall finishes to improve the EWS1 ratingPlanning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	The impact on the character and appearance of the area;-	The impact upon neighbouring properties; and -	Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearancePolicy CS8 of the Core Strategy states that the Council will protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. Policy DM10 states that development proposals will be required to incorporate principles of good design.The proposal seeks to replace all of the existing weatherboarding and EWI system that have been identified as combustible with non-combustible variants without visually altering the appearance of the building.In addition, the proposal includes the replacement of the Curtain Walling System on the west facing elevation (Skerne Road); this is to correct the fire spread related latent defect around the curtain walling openings.The replacement materials will have the same visual effect as the existing, and they will not have any adverse effect on the character and appearance of the existing street scene.Residential AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy advises that development must have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. The proposed development would not cause any material harm to the outlook, daylight/sunlight provision of the neighbouring occupiers. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.ConclusionThe proposal does not result in any harm to the amenity of neighbouring residents and is considered to be acceptable in terms of impact to the streetscene.RecommendationThat planning permission be GRANTED.

The application site is located on the pavement on the south side of Elm Road opposite the junction of Cross Road and west of the junction with York Road.The surrounding area is predominantly residential in character and appearance. The site is not in a conservation area and the buildings and curtilage are not statutorily or locally listed. 21 objections have been received objecting to the siting and appearance of the proposed telecoms apparatus. The application seeks to determine whether the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority is required for the siting and appearance of the proposed installation of 20m high slim-line monopole, supporting 6 no. antennas,1 no. wraparound equipment cabinet at the base of the monopole, 2 no. equipment cabinets, 1 no. electric meter cabinets, 1no. GPS module and ancillary developmentThe application has been assessed against the provisions of Schedule 2 Part 16 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended. The application has also been assessed against the policies of the National Planning Policy Framework and the current Development Plan policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.The National Planning Policy Framework 2021 is clear at paragraph 118 in as much as the Local Planning Authority should not question need. Local planning authorities must determine applications on planning grounds only. They should not seek to prevent competition between different operators, question the need for an electronic communications system, or set health safeguards different from the International Commission guidelines for public exposure.This application is for prior approval, not for planning permission. Prior approval is a light-touch process which applies where the principle of the development has already been established (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 028 Reference ID: 13-028-20140306).Prior approval means that a developer has to seek approval from the local planning authority that specified elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed. The matters for prior approval vary depending on the type of development and these are set out in full in the relevant parts in Schedule 2 to the General Permitted Development Order. A local planning authority cannot consider any other matters when determining a prior approval application (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 026 Reference ID: 13-026-20140306).The main considerations of the case are: - Siting and; - AppearanceThe proposed telecom apparatus would be sited in a highly visible location  on Elm Road opposite and adjacent to a number of residential properties.The height of the mast would be 20m which would be in excess of 10 to 12m higher than a standard street lamp column (10m) and a telegraph pole (8m) which are typical other such perpendicular pieces of street furniture found in the locality. It is considered that the proposal would result in an incongruous addition to the streetscene that would be visually intrusive and create visual clutter and detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.It is considered that the siting and appearance would be inappropriate in this case and it is recommended that prior approval be refused as it would not accord with policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The need for an upgraded, modern telecommunications network is both acknowledged and appreciated, and indeed is given great weight in the decision making process; however, for the reasons cited above it is considered that the harm caused by the proposed installation would outweigh the benefits. In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably. Amendments required to make the application acceptable are substantial and would materially change the development proposal.  They would require further consultation to be undertaken prior to determination which could not take place within the statutory determination period specified by the Department of Communities and Local Government.

Application SiteThe site is semi-detached dwelling is located on a private residential road composed of predominantly 1920's 'inter-war' style detached properties. The site is not in a conservation area and is not statutorily or locally listed.ProposalThe proposal is for the demolition of existing debilitated garage/ lean-to structure and erection of single-storey side extension with front and rear access.Consultation:No representations were received from neighbouring occupiers.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Highway SafetyPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the attached garage/storage space. The area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used for parking of cars, and so the conversion does not result in the loss of a space that would adversely impact upon highway safety.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. Officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend the materials on the elevations on the sides of the second storey piggyback extension from brick to a mixture of tile to match the existing roof slope, and render to match the rear of the house. In this case the applicant seeks to amend the proposal in such a way that would require an assessment of the merits of the changes and as such would fall outside the remit of a Section 96a application. Given the change in material and prominence of the extension within the surrounding area an assessment would have to be made to ensure that there is no adverse impact on the character and appearance of the surrounding area. As such, the proposed changes are considered not to be non-material.

Whether or not a proposed amendment is considered to be non-material will depend on the circumstances of the case. There is no statutory definition of 'non material'. This is because it will be dependant on the context of the overall scheme - what may be non-material in one context may be material in another. Whether or not a change can be considered as a "non-material amendment" may be defined according to established legal concepts of materiality and de minimis. The local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under section 96A. The local planning authority does not assess the acceptability of the proposed amendment but its magnitude.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling located on Eaton Avenue.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Demolition of existing garage and erection of single storey wrap around side and rear extension. Alteration to front porch.The proposal  relates to the refused planning application ref no 22/02668/HOU for Demolition of existing garage and erection of two storey-side and single-storey rear extension and alterations to front porch dated 12.10.2022Consultations8 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Loss of parking- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: It is noted that the proposed front and side extension incorporating a porch would introduce a separation gap of approximately 0.9m. The proposed conversion of the garage into a habitable room with associated alterations is considered acceptable as the existing street scene contains similar examples. The proposed roof form over the front extension is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. As such the proposed front and side elements of the proposal are considered to follow Policy Guidance 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The proposed single storey rear extension due to its modest scale, siting and the proposed design is considered to appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host dwelling, in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is noted that No 16 Eaton Avenue benefits from the rear extensions, therefore the proposed rear extension also due to its scale would not adversely affect amenities of the occupiers of this adjoining property. The proposed two storey side extension would not result in an unacceptable impact on any habitable windows at No 12 Eaton Avenue, as per available planning history for this adjoining property. The proposed rear extension due to its modest scale and siting would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to this property. Officers note the extended, raised patio area and the proposed privacy screens.  As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Loss of Car ParkingParagraph 111 of the NPPF, 2021 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. The submitted information indicates that the existing garage and forecourt area are not of sufficient size to accommodate a car (the required size of hardstaning is 4.8m x 2.7m). Therefore it is accepted that it is not possible to accommodate an average sized car in either the garage or the forecourt area and so it can reasonably be concluded that the proposal will not result in any overspill parking on surrounding roads or result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. Officers note no parking restrictions on Eton Avenue.As such it is considered that the proposal is in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.In relation to cycle parking, the applicant has indicated a cycle parking provision in the rear garden to compensate for the loss of the garage.  Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, which is considered acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalDemolition of existing rear conservatory and erection of single storey rear extension.Consultationsix neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note that the existing conservatory consists of a solid 3 metre wall on the boundary with No. 11 Malden Hill Gardens, For this reason, it is considered there will be no further loss of light should the proposed rear extension be approved. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe application site a two-storey, semi-detached residential dwellinghouse.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear extension.Consultation3x no. properties were notified of the proposal. No representations received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; and,- Fire safetyCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Case officer response: It is considered that the proposed development would preserve and maintain the character of the area and would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property, in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Case officer response: The proposed rear extension would project to a depth of 3.75 metres, which slightly exceeds SPD guidelines, however, it would project less than this beyond the rear building line of N0.81. The extension would be set away from the common shared boundary with no.81 Cobham Road by 0.12 metres. Overall and in terms of residential amenity the proposal is considered to comply with policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 and the Council's Residential Design SPD, 2013.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionThe  proposals are considered to relate well to the original dwelling, would be subordinate in scale and would not have an unacceptably adverse impact upon neighbouring residential amenity, thereby complying with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 and the Residential Design Guide, 2013.The scheme is therefore considered to be acceptable and in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that retrospective planning permission should be granted

Application SiteThe site comprises detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey front extension including extension to garage.ConsultationSeven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been receivedAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire Safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The application site is a detached property within a row of bungalows. The surrounding bungalows are of similar design but it is noted each has its own stand-alone character. The proposed development would in fill an area between the front door and garage, extending the building line forward by approximately 1 metre but remaining set back from the front building line of the neighbouring property No. 41 Oakdene Drive. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwellinghouse.17 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Relevant Planning History22/02465/HOU - Erection of single storey rear extension - Refused 23/09/2022The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - Fire Safety DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would have a reduced proposed depth of 3m, which would fall within the parameters set out in the Residential Design SPD, 2013 of 3.5m and would not be completely visible for the streetscene. Therefore, the proposed erection of single storey rear extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would be unlikely to adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The information submitted pursuant to Condition 3 (Fire Strategy) of planning permission 21/03164/FUL (Conversion of existing ground floor, five bedroom HMO to create 2no. one-bedroom self-contained residential units with associated cycle parking facilities and refuse/recycling facilities has been assessed by Officers and is considered acceptable.

The site comprises a commercial unit located on the ground floor within Kingston Town Centre. The site is not within a conservation area. 22 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered appropriate for a commercial premises and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: A condition to restrict the hours which the fascia signs can be illuminated and a condition to limit the illumination level of the signs is proposed. Subject to the satisfaction of these conditions it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties. Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy seeks to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions and does not contribute to congestion, on street car parking pressure, or compromise pedestrian or highway safety. Officer Comment: Officers consider that the proposals would not be significantly different from the existing situation and would therefore have no adverse impact upon highways and transportation, thereby complying with Core Strategy Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Rear Elevations - You submitted new Plan 01. The file name was Existing Rear Elevation, but the plan shows the Existing Ground Floor Plan. Please provide Existing and Proposed Rear Elevations, i.e. the view from 185 Elm Road. Elevations must be at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions. A scale bar is encouraged.

Annotated dimensions must be included on all Existing and Proposed floor plans, site plans, elevation drawings, and section/level plans to show the key dimensions of any existing structures to be demolished/retained and dimensions for the proposed works. This is in line with the Council's adopted local Validation Checklist. Please amend plans and re-submit where necessary.

As required by the Government's 'National List' of Validation Criteria for Planning Applications this type of application needs to be accompanied by a Design and Access Statement.  The Design and Access Statement should explain the design principles and concepts that have been applied when designing the development. It should be proportionate to the development proposed and in some cases will not need to be more than a page in length.

It should be proportionate to the development proposed and in some cases will not need to be more than a page in length.
